evidence.pdf_reference: chromogenic agent (Experimental Section S1.2 in Supporting Information). 2.3.Photocatalytic Performance Tests.The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activities of catalysts were tested in a 200 mL stainlesssteel reactor with a 300 W Xenon lamp (PLS-SXE300, Beijing Perfectlight Co., Ltd.) as the light source.The catalyst powders (20 mg) were dispersed on a glass substrate uniformly and placed into the stainless-steel reactor.Prior to photoreduction CO 2 tests, the reactor was vacuum-treated and scavenged with

of the catalyst, but also modified the pathway of water oxidation.Further studies on intermediate products and the density functional theory calculation confirm that the Cl -ions on Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets not only promote H 2 O oxidation, but also lower the energy barrier for intermediate CHO generation, thus facilitating CH 4 production.The results gained herein may provide some illuminating insights into the design of a highly selective photocatalyst for efficient CO 2 reduction.

Solar-driven photocatalytic CO 2 reduction into CH 4 with H 2 O is considered to be a promising way to alleviate the energy crisis and greenhouse effect.However, current CO 2 photoreduction technologies tend to overlook the role of photooxidation half reaction as well as the effect of the protons produced by water oxidation on CH 4 generation, resulting in low CO 2 conversion efficiency and poor CH 4 selectivity.In the present study, a series of chloride-modified Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets were constructed in

(SEM; Carl Zeiss Sigma 500) were used to observe the morphology of the synthesized samples.The crystal orientation of the samples was determined by a high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image and a fast-Fourier transform (FFT) diffraction pattern.UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS; Agilent Cary 5000) were obtained to investigate the light-harvesting ability of the catalysts.Raman spectra (Renishaw InVia) were employed to characterize the surface structure of the catalysts.The CO 2 adsorption ability was

to detect the O 2 yield.It should be noted that apart from CO and CH 4 , other products, including H 2 , C 2 H 4 , C 2 H 6 , HCHO, and CH 3 OH, were not detected within the detection limits of our instrument.The 13 C isotope tracing technique was carried out under identical conditions to verify the source of CH 4 and CO.The obtained products were identified by a gas chromatography-mass spectrometer (GC-MS, Agilent 7890B and OmniStar GSD 320). 2.4.Theoretical Calculations.Density functional theory (DFT)
